description: Consider 2n tennis players; a(n) is the number of matches needed to let every possible pair play each other.
comments: Number of matchings of size two (edges) in a complete graph on 2n vertices.
links: Vincenzo Librandi, Table of n, a(n) for n = 2..1000
formula: a(n) = n*(4*n^3 - 12*n^2 + 11*n -3)/2. - Swapnil P. Bhatia (sbhatia(AT)cs.unh.edu), Jul 20 2006a(n+1) = (2*n+2)*(2*n+1)*(2*n)*(2*n-1)/8. - _James Mahoney_, Oct 19 2011G.f.: x^2*(3+30*x+15*x^2)/(1-x)^5. - _Vincenzo Librandi_, Oct 13 2013a(n) = binomial(2n^2-3n+1, 2). - _Wesley Ivan Hurt_, Oct 14 2013
example: a(2)=3: given players a,b,c,d, the matches needed are (ab,cd), (ac,bd), (ad,bc).For example, for the K_4 on vertices {0,1,2,3} the possible matchings of size two are: {{0,1}, {2,3}}, {{0,3},{1,2}} and {{0,2},{1,3}}.
mathematica: CoefficientList[Series[(3 + 30 x + 15 x^2)/(1 - x)^5, {x, 0, 40}], x] (* _Vincenzo Librandi_, Oct 13 2013 *)
author: Michel ten Voorde (seqfan(AT)tenvoorde.org) Jul 06 2001
extensions: More terms from Swapnil P. Bhatia (sbhatia(AT)cs.unh.edu), Jul 20 2006
